bestBHT.bht: The inclusion of verses from Isaiah in Luke 3:4 adds to the prophetic citation found in the other gospel accounts. The addition of these verses serves to emphasize the preparation of the way for the Lord and the importance of making His paths straight. By drawing from Isaiah's words, Luke deepens our understanding of the prophetic fulfillment of the Messiah's arrival and the significance of preparing for His coming.

Marvin Vincent: In this prophetic citation Mark adds to Isaiah Malachi 3:1, which does not appear in either Matthew or Luke.
Luke adds vv. 4, 5 of Isaiah 40:0, which do not appear in the others.
Paths [τριβους] . From tribw, to rub or wear. Hence beaten tracks.
Philip Schaff: Luke 3:4. Matthew and Mark also quote Isaiah 40:3, but no more.
Archibald T. Robertson: As it is written (ως γεγραπτα). The regular formula for quotation."
Isaiah the prophet (Εσαιου του προφητου). The same phrase in Mark 1:2 and Matthew 3:3.
Mark, as we have seen, adds a quotation from Malachi 3:1 and Luke gives verses 4 and 5 of Luke 3:40 not in Matthew or Mark.
John Gill: As it is written in the book of the words of Esaias the prophet....
Prepare ye the way of the Lord make his paths straight.
The voice of one crying in the wilderness.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 3:4, Luke adds verses 4 and 5 of Isaiah 40:0, which are not found in the other gospel accounts. The phrase paths refers to beaten tracks, highlighting the prophetic citation of Isaiah. Mark also includes a quotation from Malachi 3:1, further emphasizing the preparation of the way of the Lord. This passage, as written in the book of Isaiah, sets the stage for the voice crying out in the wilderness, urging the people to prepare the way for the Lord by making His paths straight. Ultimately, Luke's inclusion of these additional verses enriches our understanding of the prophetic fulfillment of the Messiah's arrival and uncovers the significance of preparing for His coming.

Luke 3:4 includes verses 4 and 5 of Isaiah 40:0, which are not found in the other gospel accounts. Mark also adds a quote from Malachi 3:1, emphasizing the preparation of the way of the Lord. The phrase paths refers to beaten tracks, highlighting Isaiah's prophetic words. These additional verses enrich our understanding of the prophetic fulfillment of the Messiah's arrival and the importance of preparing for His coming.

Luke includes additional verses from Isaiah that are not found in the other gospel accounts, emphasizing the preparation of the way for the Lord. The phrase paths refers to beaten tracks, as written in the book of Isaiah. These passages enrich our understanding of the prophetic fulfillment of the Messiah's arrival, urging us to prepare for His coming.

The inclusion of verses from Isaiah in Luke 3:4 adds to the prophetic citation found in the other gospel accounts. The addition of these verses serves to emphasize the preparation of the way for the Lord and the importance of making His paths straight. By drawing from Isaiah's words, Luke deepens our understanding of the prophetic fulfillment of the Messiah's arrival and the significance of preparing for His coming.

Luke's inclusion of verses from Isaiah distinguishes his account from the other gospel versions, highlighting the significance of preparing the way for the Lord by making His paths straight. These additional verses deepen our understanding of the prophetic fulfillment of the Messiah's arrival. By drawing from Isaiah's words, Luke emphasizes the importance of readiness and the necessity to pave the way for the Lord's coming.
